questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cystic fibrosis?
Identify the diagnosis in the MRI below:
Which of the following Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERMs) is approved for the treatment of senile vaginitis (atrophic vaginitis)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ospemifene

 

Senile (Atrophic) Vaginitis:

 

  • Occurs in postmenopausal women due to estrogen deficiency, leading to: 
    • Thinning of the vaginal epithelium
    • Decreased lubrication
    • Vaginal dryness, itching, dyspareunia, and recurrent infections
  • Ospemifene is the only SERM approved specifically for the treatment of moderate to severe dyspareunia and vaginal atrophy due to menopause.
  • Mechanism: 
    • Acts as a selective estrogen receptor agonist on vaginal and vulvar tissues
    • Improves vaginal epithelial maturation, increases superficial cell layers, and restores vaginal pH and elasticity
    • Has anti-estrogenic effects on the breast and neutral effects on the endometrium.
  • Indication: Postmenopausal atrophic vaginitis (senile vaginitis)
  • Administered orally (60 mg once daily)
  • Other treatment Options for Vaginal Atrophy: 
    • Non-hormonal options for vaginal dryness (non-prescription):
      • Moisturizers: e.g., Replens, Silk-E, RepHresh (lowers vaginal pH)
      • Lubricants: e.g., K-Y Jelly, Lubrin, Astroglide 
      • Oils: vitamin E, olive oil
    • Vaginal estrogen therapy options for vaginal atrophy:
      • Estrogen vaginal creams: estradial (Estrace Vaginal), conjugated estrogens (Premarin Vaginal) – Daily for 2 weeks, then 1-3 times per week 
      • Estradiol hemihydrate vaginal tablet (Vagifem) – Daily for 2 weeks, then 2 times per week 
      • Estradiol vaginal ring (Estring) – Once every 3 months 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clomiphene: Acts as an anti-estrogen at the hypothalamus, stimulating ovulation in infertility treatment. No role in atrophic vaginitis.

 

Option C. Tamoxifen: Estrogen antagonist in breast tissue, agonist in endometrium and bone. Used in breast cancer therapy and prevention. Causes endometrial hyperplasia, not suitable for vaginal atrophy.

 

Option D. Raloxifene: Estrogen agonist in bone and lipid metabolism; antagonist in breast and uterus. Used in osteoporosis prevention and treatment in postmenopausal women. No beneficial effect on vaginal epithelium or lubrication.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic in her 8th week of pregnancy with complaints of palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance. On examination, she has a resting heart rate of 110 bpm, tremors, and mild exophthalmos. Laboratory results show: 

 

TSH <0.01 µIU/mL

Free T4Elevated

Total T3Elevated

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate choice for managing her symptoms?

A 29-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of yellowing of the skin and eyes. He denies other symptoms and recalls a similar episode three years ago. Recently, he has noticed dark urine. Laboratory tests reveal a serum bilirubin level of 4.6 mg/dL, predominantly conjugated. Serum AST and ALT levels are within normal limits. A liver biopsy is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dubin-Johnson syndrome

 

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive condition characterized by a defect in the hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin into bile. 
  • This results in chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which is usually asymptomatic but may present with mild jaundice triggered by stress, illness, or fasting.
  • Histological hallmark: The presence of darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, as seen in the biopsy, is characteristic of Dubin-Johnson syndrome. The pigment is thought to be a derivative of epinephrine metabolites that accumulate in lysosomes.
  • Patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome typically have normal liver enzyme levels (AST, ALT, and alkaline phosphatase), distinguishing it from other liver disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotor syndrome: Rotor syndrome also causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but it lacks the dark pigmentation of hepatocytes seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome. Additionally, patients with Rotor syndrome do not have any hepatic histological abnormalities on biopsy.

 

Option C. Gilbert syndrome: Gilbert syndrome is characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of the enzyme uridine diphosphate-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1). It does not cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or histological abnormalities.

 

Option D. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: Crigler-Najjar syndrome involves severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to an inherited deficiency of UGT1A1. It does not cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or liver pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive condition characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to impaired hepatic excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Liver biopsy reveals darkly pigmented granules in hepatocytes, a hallmark of the condition.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to an acute episode of heavy menstrual bleeding. The patient has a history of menorrhagia, with monthly cycles lasting 7-10 days and brisk blood flow with the passage of large clots. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged fibroid uterus, and she is found to have significant anemia due to blood loss. The patient is prescribed continuous leuprolide therapy. After several weeks, which of the following sustained hormonal changes are expected to have occurred as a result of the treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GnRH low, FSH low, Estrogen low

 

Step 1: Diagnosis — Uterine fibroids (leiomyoma)

 

  • Common cause of menorrhagia with clots and uterine enlargement.
  • Estrogen-dependent tumor — shrinks with hypoestrogenic states (e.g., menopause or GnRH analog therapy).

 

Step 2: Mechanism of Leuprolide

 

  • Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist (a synthetic analog of gonadotropin-releasing hormone). Its effect depends on administration pattern:

 

 

Step 3: Phases of Action

 

  1. Initial phase (“flare”): Short-term increase in LH, FSH, and estrogen due to pituitary stimulation.
  2. Sustained phase (after 2–4 weeks): Continuous exposure leads to desensitization and downregulation of GnRH receptors in the anterior pituitary. Result: Suppression of gonadotropins (FSH, LH) → reduced ovarian estrogen production.

 

Step 4: Hormonal Pattern (after several weeks):

 

 

Hence: GnRH low, FSH low, Estrogen low

 

Step 5: Clinical Utility in This Case- Fibroids (leiomyoma): Estrogen promotes growth → suppressing estrogen shrinks fibroids and reduces bleeding. Short-term use (≤6 months) is effective for preoperative correction of anemia and reducing uterine volume. Long-term use causes menopausal side effects (hot flashes, vaginal dryness, bone loss).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH high, FSH low, Estrogen low: GnRH secretion itself is not reduced; rather, its effect is blocked by receptor downregulation. Functionally, pituitary "perceives" low GnRH activity → similar to a low GnRH state.

 

Option C. GnRH high, FSH high, Estrogen high: Represents the initial flare phase, not the sustained effect.

 

Option D. GnRH high, FSH high, Estrogen low: Impossible combination; persistent FSH elevation would maintain estrogen production.

questions.text: All of the following may be done for cervical cause of infertility except:
Which ovarian structure is responsible for the following finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpus luteum

 

Corpus luteum — source of progesterone → secretory transformation of endometrium

 

  • After ovulation, the ruptured Graafian follicle transforms into the corpus luteum under the influence of LH. 
  • The granulosa lutein cells and theca lutein cells secrete progesterone (and some estrogen). 
  • Progesterone acts on the proliferative endometrium (previously estrogen-primed) and converts it into secretory endometrium.

 

Histologic features (as seen in image):

 

  • Tortuous, coiled glands with subnuclear vacuolation (early secretory phase). 
  • Edematous stroma rich in glycogen and spiral arterioles. 
  • Indicates progesterone activity → hence, corpus luteum is responsible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secondary follicle: Secretes mainly estrogen, responsible for proliferative phase endometrium (straight glands, dense stroma). Not responsible for secretory changes.

 

Option B. Theca interna: Produces androgens, which are later aromatized to estrogens by granulosa cells. Indirect role in follicular estrogen synthesis, not secretory transformation.

 

Option C. Granulosa cell: In preovulatory follicle, secretes estrogen, leading to proliferation of endometrium. After ovulation, these become granulosa lutein cells, secreting progesterone as part of corpus luteum. So, granulosa cells alone (pre-ovulation) do not cause secretory endometrium.

questions.solution:
Ans. D) HLA-DQ6/DQ11 are genetic markers associated with the disease

 

Celiac disease is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8, not DQ6/DQ11.

 

Other Options:

Option B. Modified Marsh criteria is used histologically: Marsh criteria classifies villous atrophy/crypt hyperplasia – correct.

A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which is shown below. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Urine examination

 

Explanation:

 

The brain CT shows periventricular calcifications, which are characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV is a common cause of intrauterine infection leading to IUGR, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and petechiae at birth. The best method for diagnosing congenital CMV infection is by detecting CMV in the urine within the first 2 to 3 weeks of life. Urinary examination detects CMV viral DNA or pp65 antigen, which is a reliable marker for infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver biopsy: Liver biopsy is invasive and not the first-line investigation for diagnosing CMV infection. While it may show histological evidence of infection, it is rarely used due to its risk and limited diagnostic value for confirming congenital CMV.

 

Option C. Blood examination: Although blood tests can detect CMV DNA or antibodies, blood examination is not the most sensitive method for the initial diagnosis of congenital CMV infection. It is often used as a secondary test rather than the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. CSF examination: CSF examination may be performed in cases of central nervous system involvement, but it is not the standard test for diagnosing congenital CMV. CSF is more commonly examined in cases of viral encephalitis caused by other viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periventricular calcifications on brain imaging, along with IUGR, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and petechiae, strongly suggest congenital CMV infection. The diagnostic test of choice is a urine examination to detect CMV viral DNA or pp65 antigen.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Only one sacral ala is present in Naegele’s pelvis 
  2. Hand prolapse must be managed by LSCS
  3. False labour is rhythmic pain that radiates to thigh and back
  4. Constriction ring is due to injudicious use of oxytocin
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1. Only one sacral ala is present in Naegele’s pelvis: Correct. Naegele’s pelvis = unilateral obliquely contracted pelvis. Caused by arrest of development of one sacral ala (hemisacrum). Results in asymmetrical pelvic inlet — oblique diameter shortened on affected side. Commonly associated with scoliosis and pelvic tilt.

 

Statement 2. Hand prolapse must be managed by LSCS: Correct. Hand prolapse: descent of hand alongside the presenting part (usually head). Indicates malpresentation or cephalopelvic disproportion. Vaginal delivery risks cord compression or trauma, hence Caesarean section (LSCS) is the management of choice.

 

Statement 3. False labour is rhythmic pain that radiates to thigh and back: Incorrect. False labour is rhythmic pain that radiates to thigh and back — Incorrect. False labour (Braxton Hicks contractions) is the irregular, non-progressive uterine contractions. Do not radiate to back or thighs. No cervical dilatation or effacement. True labour pain is the one that is rhythmic, increases in intensity, and radiates to the back and thighs → causes cervical changes.

 

Statement 4. Constriction ring is due to injudicious use of oxytocin: Correct. Constriction ring (Schröder’s ring): Localized uterine contraction around a fetal part, usually due to hyperstimulation by oxytocics.

He has been experiencing recurrent episodes of coughing and shortness of breath over the past few months. He also complains of fatigue and chest pain, particularly on the left side. The CT scan reveals a mass in the lower lobe of his left lung as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old P1L1 presents with acute abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on oral Warfarin. On examination, 14 weeks’ abdominal mass was felt. On USG, 8 x 6 cm unilocular cyst with reticular pattern was observed in left ovary. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat USG after 6-12 weeks

 

Likely diagnosis - Functional (Hemorrhagic) Ovarian Cyst — Conservative Management

 

  • Unilocular cyst with reticular (“lace-like” or “fishnet”) pattern on USG → suggests a hemorrhagic (functional) cyst.
  • Functional cysts are benign, hormone-related, and usually regress spontaneously within 6–12 weeks. As the patient is on Warfarin (anticoagulant), hemorrhagic cyst formation is common due to bleeding into a functional follicle.
  • Hence, expectant management with repeat USG after 6–12 weeks is the safest approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure CA-125: CA-125 is useful for postmenopausal or suspicious adnexal masses, not for young women with classic benign cystic pattern. In premenopausal women, CA-125 may be falsely elevated due to menstruation, endometriosis, or inflammation. Hence, not the next step here.

 

Option C. Surgical intervention: Indicated only if: Persistent or enlarging cyst, Complex/solid mass, Torsion or rupture, Malignancy suspected

Here, benign pattern + young age + on Warfarin → conservative approach preferred.

 

Option D. MRI pelvis: Used for indeterminate USG findings or complex adnexal lesions when diagnosis is unclear. Here, ultrasound appearance is typical of hemorrhagic cyst, so MRI not required.

 

Summary of Ovarian cyst management:

questions.text: A 9-month-old male infant develops progressive renal and hepatic failure. Despite intensive medical therapy, he passes away. Autopsy reveals kidneys with the gross appearance shown in the image below. Which of the following is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal recessive

 

  • The described condition is autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), a severe form of cystic kidney disease that presents in infancy. 
  • The disease is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene, which encodes fibrocystin, a protein involved in renal and biliary duct development. 
  • The linear arrangement of cysts within the kidneys is characteristic of ARPKD, as the cysts originate from dilated collecting ducts. 
  • ARPKD often leads to progressive renal failure and hepatic fibrosis, contributing to mortality in affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondrial inheritance: Mitochondrial inheritance is associated with conditions caused by mutations in mitochondrial DNA, typically affecting energy-dependent organs like the brain and muscles. It is not related to polycystic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Autosomal dominant: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) presents later in life, typically in adulthood, with cysts randomly distributed throughout the kidneys. It does not exhibit the smooth external surface or the linear cyst pattern seen in ARPKD.

 

Option D. Multifactorial inheritance: Multifactorial inheritance involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors. While multifactorial inheritance can underlie some conditions, it is not the cause of ARPKD, which follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) presents in infancy with smooth external kidney surfaces and linear cysts on cut section. 
  • It is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene, leading to renal and hepatic failure.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with polyuria, polydipsia, progressive vision loss, and a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Further evaluation reveals optic atrophy, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, and diabetes insipidus. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of DIDMOAD syndrome. Which of the following genes is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) WFS1

 

  • DIDMOAD syndrome (also known as Wolfram Syndrome) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by Diabetes Insipidus, Diabetes Mellitus, Optic Atrophy, and Deafness. 
  • It is most commonly caused by mutations in the WFS1 gene, which encodes wolframin, a protein involved in endoplasmic reticulum homeostasis. 
  • The syndrome typically presents in childhood or adolescence with diabetes mellitus and progressive optic atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FOXP3: Mutations in FOXP3 are associated with IPEX syndrome, not DIDMOAD.

 

Option C. HNF1A: Mutations in HNF1A are associated with MODY (Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young).

 

Option D. PDX1: Mutations in PDX1 are linked to pancreatic development defects and some forms of neonatal diabetes but not DIDMOAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WFS1 gene mutations are responsible for DIDMOAD syndrome (Wolfram Syndrome), which presents with a combination of diabetes mellitus, diabetes insipidus, optic atrophy, and deafness.

A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CPAM

 

Explanation:

 

The images provided, including ultrasound, CT scan, and X-ray findings, are consistent with Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM).

 

Key features of CPAM:

 

  1. Ultrasound: Shows multiple cystic spaces within the lung parenchyma.
  2. CT scan: Confirms the presence of air-filled cystic lesions in the lung fields.
  3. X-ray: May show cystic areas or hyperinflation, depending on the size and type of lesions.

 

CPAM is a congenital condition characterized by abnormal development of the lung tissue, leading to the formation of cystic or adenomatoid lesions. It often presents in childhood with recurrent respiratory infections due to impaired drainage and ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This would present with an air-fluid level and features of infection (fever, acute symptoms), which are not the primary findings here.

 

Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH presents with abdominal contents herniating into the thoracic cavity, causing mediastinal shift and respiratory distress, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: Lung abscess typically presents as a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid levels, which is not the pattern seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to abnormal lung development and cystic changes. Imaging studies, including ultrasound and CT, confirm the diagnosis by identifying multiple cystic lesions within the lung.

questions.text: An 18-year-old primigravida at 27 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department due to severe right upper quadrant pain. The pain started 2 hours ago, and the patient has also had nausea, vomiting, and irregular uterine contractions. Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT) is 220 U/L and alanine aminotransferase (SGPT) is 240 U/L. CECT is shown below. This patient is most likely at risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seizures

 

  • The CT image shows a subcapsular hepatic hematoma, which is a severe complication of HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets)—a variant of severe preeclampsia. 
  • The patient’s presentation of right upper quadrant pain, elevated transaminases, nausea, and vomiting during pregnancy strongly suggests this diagnosis. 
  • The hematoma results from hepatic sinusoidal distention and rupture of subcapsular vessels due to endothelial damage. 
  • As HELLP is a manifestation of severe preeclampsia, the patient is at high risk of developing eclampsia (seizures) if not promptly managed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: Is a hypersensitivity reaction caused by medications such as antibiotics or NSAIDs, characterized by fever, rash, and eosinophiluria. In HELLP syndrome, renal injury results instead from preeclampsia-induced vasospasm and glomerular endotheliosis, not from an allergic or drug-related mechanism.

 

Option B. Bleeding esophageal varices: Occur as a consequence of portal hypertension from chronic liver disease such as cirrhosis. HELLP syndrome causes acute hepatic injury and subcapsular hematoma but not chronic fibrosis or portal hypertension, so variceal bleeding is not a risk here.

 

Option C. Intraamniotic infection (chorioamnionitis): Typically presents with maternal fever, uterine tenderness, foul-smelling amniotic fluid, and fetal tachycardia. This patient’s presentation of severe right upper quadrant pain and elevated liver enzymes is unrelated to infection and instead points toward hepatic vascular injury secondary to preeclampsia.

They are not painful and occur every 7-15 minutes. She has had no vaginal bleeding or leakage of fluid. Fetal movement is normal. The patient's pregnancy has been uncomplicated. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and has no palpable contractions. Fundal height is at 36 cm. The cervix is closed on digital cervical examination. Blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. BMI is 28 kg/m2. Nonstress test monitoring is shown in the exhibit. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 37 weeks gestation is brought to the emergency department with constant, excruciating abdominal pain and sudden vaginal bleeding for the past 3 hours. The patient is Rh negative and received Rh(D) immunoglobulin at 28 weeks gestation. Blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and pulse is 118/min. Physical examination shows a firm and tender uterus. Speculum examination reveals a moderate amount of bleeding coming from an open cervical os. Fetal heart tracing shows a baseline of 105/min and no variability. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Premature placental separation

 

  • Premature placental separation, or placental abruption, occurs when the placenta detaches from the uterine wall before delivery, leading to painful vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and fetal distress. 
  • The patient’s severe, constant abdominal pain, firm tender uterus, hypertension, and non-reassuring foetal heart pattern (bradycardia with absent variability) are classic findings. 
  • The bleeding is typically dark and may be accompanied by concealed hemorrhage, making the uterus tense and rigid. 
  • Chronic hypertension and preeclampsia are key risk factors, as seen here with elevated blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Attachment of the placenta onto the myometrium (placenta accreta): Presents with adherent placenta and severe postpartum hemorrhage at delivery, not antepartum pain or bleeding.
 

Option B. Injury to fetal placental vessels (vasa previa): Causes painless, rapid fetal exsanguination with bright red bleeding at membrane rupture, not a tender, firm uterus.
 

Option C. Placental implantation over the cervix (placenta previa): Results in painless, bright red bleeding and a soft, nontender uterus; pain and uterine rigidity are absent.

An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2; LH 0.3; TSH 1.2; Prolactin 20 ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

 

  • This patient’s low BMI, secondary amenorrhea, and infertility suggest functional hypothalamic amenorrhea due to energy deficiency from excessive exercise or inadequate caloric intake. 
  • The laboratory findings show low FSH and LH with normal TSH and prolactin, confirming suppression of the hypothalamic–pituitary–gonadal axis. 
  • Decreased pulsatile GnRH secretion leads to reduced gonadotropin levels, causing anovulation and hypoestrogenism—typical of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Primary ovarian failure: Would present with elevated FSH and LH due to loss of ovarian feedback inhibition, unlike the low levels seen here.

 

Option C. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism: Also features high gonadotropins with low estrogen, commonly due to ovarian failure or gonadal dysgenesis, not seen in this athlete.


Option D. Normogonadotropic normogonadism: Occurs in conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), where FSH and LH levels are normal or mildly elevated, not suppressed as in this case.

A 32-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a positive pregnancy test, but transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Endometrial biopsy reveals hypersecretory glands with nuclear atypia and poor decidualization. This histological finding is consistent with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arias-Stella reaction

 

  • The Arias-Stella reaction is a histological finding characterized by hypersecretory endometrial glands with nuclear atypia, often associated with ectopic pregnancy. 
  • This reaction occurs due to exposure of the endometrium to abnormal hormonal levels, particularly low progesterone, which leads to poor decidualization. 
  • The presence of these atypical hypersecretory changes is a key diagnostic clue when evaluating for ectopic pregnancy in a patient with a positive pregnancy test and no evidence of an intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometritis: Endometritis is characterized by infiltration of the endometrium with neutrophils or plasma cells, depending on whether the infection is acute or chronic. It does not involve the hypersecretory glandular changes or nuclear atypia seen in the Arias-Stella reaction.

 

Option C. Decidual reaction: A decidual reaction refers to the normal histological transformation of endometrial stromal cells into decidual cells during pregnancy, induced by progesterone. Unlike the Arias-Stella reaction, decidualization is associated with a well-developed and organized appearance of the endometrium, without nuclear atypia or hypersecretory changes.

 

Option D. Chronic inflammation: Chronic inflammation of the endometrium is marked by plasma cell infiltration and is typically associated with chronic infections or autoimmune conditions. It is not associated with the hypersecretory changes or nuclear atypia characteristic of the Arias-Stella reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Arias-Stella reaction is a histological hallmark of ectopic pregnancy. 
  • It is characterized by hypersecretory glands with nuclear atypia and is caused by inadequate hormonal support, particularly low progesterone, leading to poor decidualization. 
  • This finding is a key diagnostic feature in patients with suspected ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Phototherapy is a commonly used treatment for neonatal jaundice to reduce elevated serum bilirubin levels. Which mechanism of action in phototherapy primarily contributes to the reduction in serum bilirubin levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Structural isomerization

 

  • The primary mechanism by which phototherapy reduces serum bilirubin is structural isomerization. 
  • Phototherapy converts the insoluble, unconjugated bilirubin (bound to albumin) into water-soluble isomers that can be excreted directly by the kidneys without further metabolism in the liver. 
  • This is essential in neonates with immature liver enzyme systems, which are not yet efficient at conjugating bilirubin for excretion.

 

Key mechanisms of phototherapy include:

 

  1. Structural isomerization: This is the predominant process. It changes the configuration of bilirubin molecules, creating isomers such as lumirubin, which is more water-soluble and can be excreted directly.
  2. Photo isomerization: This involves altering the double bonds in bilirubin molecules, converting them into a form that can also be excreted but is a less significant contributor.
  3. Photo oxidation: A minor mechanism where bilirubin is oxidized into water-soluble products that are excreted in urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photo oxidation: While it does contribute slightly, it is not the primary mechanism for reducing bilirubin levels.

 

Option B. Photo isomerization: This mechanism helps in altering bilirubin's structure but is not as significant as structural isomerization.

 

Option D. Conjugation: This occurs in the liver and is not directly related to phototherapy, as phototherapy bypasses the need for hepatic conjugation by creating water-soluble isomers.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The primary mechanism of phototherapy in reducing bilirubin is structural isomerization, which transforms unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers that can be excreted directly by the kidneys.

questions.text: A full-term baby was born 14 hours ago. As the pediatrician on duty, you are called to assess the newborn for a routine check-up. On examination, the baby appears well, with no apparent abnormalities. The mother, however, expresses concern as the baby has not yet passed any stool or urine. She asks for clarification on what is considered the normal time frame for a newborn to pass urine and meconium. What would be the appropriate response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours

 

  • In a healthy, full-term newborn, it is expected for the first urine to be passed within 24 hours after birth and for the first meconium to be passed within 48 hours. 
  • Delays beyond this time frame could indicate underlying conditions, such as congenital urinary tract obstruction, meconium ileus, or other gastrointestinal issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urine within 12 hours and meconium within 24 hours: While it is possible for some newborns to pass urine and meconium earlier than the standard time frame, the average expected time for urine and meconium is within 24 and 48 hours, respectively.

 

Option C. Urine within 24 hours and meconium within 12 hours: Meconium passage within 12 hours may occur, but the upper limit is typically considered 48 hours.

 

Option D. Urine within 48 hours and meconium within 24 hours: Delayed urine passage beyond 24 hours is not typical and warrants further investigation for potential urinary tract issues.

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • A healthy, full-term newborn is expected to pass urine within 24 hours and meconium within 48 hours after birth. 
  • Delays beyond these time frames may indicate underlying pathologies and require medical evaluation.

Six hours after delivery, the patient developed tachypnoea, grunting, and cyanosis, a chest x-ray revealed ground-glass opacities. Ever since ventilation was discontinued, the patient has remained hypoxic and continues to require oxygen administration by nasal cannula. Chest radiograph is shown below. A 6-year-old girl is evaluated for early-onset puberty and multiple bone lesions. On examination, she has café-au-lait spots as shown below. Hormonal tests confirm hyperfunction of multiple endocrine glands. What is the underlying genetic mutation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GNAS gene mutation

 

  • The child has café-au-lait spots with irregular borders ("coast of Maine" appearance).
  • Associated with precocious puberty, fibrous dysplasia of bone, and endocrine hyperfunction (eg, hyperthyroidism, Cushing’s, acromegaly).
  • The underlying defect is a somatic activating mutation of the GNAS gene, leading to constitutive activation of G-protein signaling and excess hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NF1 gene: Neurofibromatosis type 1; café-au-lait spots but with smooth ("coast of California") borders, neurofibromas, optic gliomas.

 

Option B. GNAQ gene mutation: Sturge–Weber syndrome; port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angiomas, seizures.

 

Option D. FGFR3: Achondroplasia; causes abnormal cartilage growth → short stature, macrocephaly.

questions.text: A 22-year-old nulligravid woman presents with worsening acne, hirsutism (coarse hair on chin and upper lip), and clitoromegaly for 6 months. Despite weight loss, symptoms persist. Her BMI is 42 kg/m², total testosterone is elevated, and DHEA-S is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor

 

  • Diagnosis: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor (Androblastoma)
  • This is a rare ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor that secretes testosterone, leading to rapid-onset virilization.

 

Key Diagnostic Clues:

 

  • Rapid onset (within months) of virilizing features → strongly suggests an androgen-secreting tumor rather than PCOS.
  • Virilization signs: clitoromegaly, deepening of voice, male pattern baldness, and marked hirsutism.
  • Hormonal pattern: ↑ Total testosterone (from ovarian source) Normal DHEA-S (rules out adrenal source)

 

Mechanism:


Sertoli and Leydig cells in the ovary produce excess androgens (testosterone) → virilization and suppression of gonadotropins → anovulation and menstrual irregularity.

 

Next Step in Management:

 

  • Pelvic ultrasound or MRI to locate ovarian mass.
  • Surgical removal (unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) is curative in most cases.

 

Key Concept: Isolated high testosterone + rapid virilization + normal DHEA-S = Ovarian androgen-secreting tumor. Most common = Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 21-hydroxylase deficiency (Congenital adrenal hyperplasia): Typically presents in childhood or adolescence with ambiguous genitalia, menstrual irregularities, and elevated DHEA-S (adrenal source). Onset is long-standing, not rapid as in this case. Here, DHEA-S is normal, excluding adrenal pathology.

 

Option B. Adrenocortical carcinoma: Produces excess DHEA-S and cortisol, leading to Cushingoid features along with virilization. This patient has isolated testosterone elevation with normal DHEA-S — inconsistent with adrenal carcinoma.

 

Option C. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): Common cause of hirsutism and acne, but the onset is gradual, and clitoromegaly is rare. Both testosterone and DHEA-S are mildly elevated in PCOS, unlike the isolated, marked elevation of testosterone here.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?

 

  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche – absent

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl is developing cataracts. Other than not having a social smile or being able to track objects visually, all other aspects of the girl’s examination are normal. Tests on the baby’s urine are positive for reducing sugar but negative for glucose. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this girl?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactokinase

 

Explanation:

 

The 3-month-old girl presents with cataracts and a positive test for reducing sugars in the urine, but negative for glucose. These findings suggest a metabolic disorder involving galactose. The deficiency of galactokinase, an enzyme responsible for the phosphorylation of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate, leads to the accumulation of galactose in the blood (galactosemia) and urine (galactosuria).

 

In the lens of the eye, accumulated galactose is converted to galactitol, a sugar alcohol, by the enzyme aldose reductase. Galactitol causes osmotic changes in the lens, leading to water retention and cataract formation. The absence of other systemic findings such as liver damage or neurologic effects, which are associated with other disorders of galactose metabolism, points to an isolated galactokinase deficiency.

 

Thus, the girl's clinical and biochemical presentation is most consistent with galactokinase deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldolase B: Aldolase B is involved in the metabolism of fructose. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to hereditary fructose intolerance, a severe disorder characterized by hypoglycemia, vomiting, failure to thrive, and liver and kidney damage upon fructose ingestion. Cataracts are not typically seen in this condition. Since the presentation in this case is related to galactose metabolism rather than fructose metabolism, aldolase B deficiency is not the correct answer.

 

Option B. Fructokinase: Fructokinase deficiency causes essential fructosuria, a benign condition in which fructose is excreted in the urine due to the inability to phosphorylate fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. This condition does not cause systemic effects, cataracts, or urine findings as described in this case. Thus, fructokinase deficiency is not relevant to the girl's clinical presentation.

 

Option D. Galactose 1-phosphate uridylyl transferase (GALT): Deficiency of GALT results in classic galactosemia, a severe condition characterized by cataracts, hepatomegaly, liver dysfunction, and neurologic effects such as developmental delay and seizures. The absence of systemic effects such as liver damage or neurologic symptoms in this child makes GALT deficiency less likely. Additionally, classic galactosemia typically presents earlier in infancy with more severe systemic involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactokinase deficiency leads to galactose accumulation, which is converted to galactitol in the lens by aldose reductase, causing cataracts.

A 35-year-old woman with symptomatic uterine fibroids is scheduled for surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon uses the instrument shown in the image. What procedure is this instrument most commonly used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open myomectomy

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp, which is primarily used in open myomectomy procedures.
  •  This clamp is designed to provide hemostasis by occluding blood vessels in the uterine tissue during the removal of fibroids (myomas). 
  • Myomectomy is a surgical procedure used to excise uterine fibroids while preserving the uterus, often performed in women who desire future fertility or want to avoid hysterectomy.
  •  The Bonney clamp allows the surgeon to control bleeding during the excision of fibroids, which is critical due to the high vascularity of the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic hysterectomy: While laparoscopic instruments are used in hysterectomy, the Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is specifically designed for open procedures, not for use in laparoscopic surgeries.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is a minimally invasive procedure used to remove or destroy the lining of the uterus to treat heavy menstrual bleeding. This procedure does not involve the use of a Bonney’s clamp, as it focuses on the endometrium rather than uterine fibroids.

 

Option D. Cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsies are small tissue samples taken from the cervix, typically during a colposcopy. A Bonney’s clamp is not needed for this procedure, which involves much smaller instruments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is commonly used during an open myomectomy to control bleeding while removing uterine fibroids.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of this placental pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Placenta succenturiata

 

  • Placenta succenturiata is characterized by the presence of one or more small accessory lobes connected to the main placenta by fetal blood vessels. 
  • Retention of these accessory lobes after delivery can lead to postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Battledore placenta: In battledore placenta, the umbilical cord is attached at the edge of the placenta, resembling a badminton racket. It does not involve accessory lobes.

 

Option B. Circumvallate placenta: Circumvallate placenta presents as a raised, thickened ridge on the maternal side of the placenta due to a double fold of chorion and amnion. It does not feature accessory lobes.

 

Option D. Velamentous placenta: Velamentous placenta involves insertion of the umbilical cord into the membranes rather than the placental disk, with exposed vessels traversing the membranes. This condition does not involve accessory lobes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta succenturiata involves the presence of accessory lobes, which may lead to postpartum hemorrhage if retained after delivery. 
  • Prompt ultrasound evaluation is critical to confirm retained tissue in such cases.

She denies vaginal bleeding, or regular uterine contractions. On examination, her abdomen is tense and tender. Laboratory investigations reveal a WBC count of 15000 cells/µl. A 27-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester visits the clinic for a routine checkup. She asks about the physiological changes occurring in her urinary system during pregnancy. Which of the following changes does not occur in the urinary system during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased activity of ureters

 

  • During pregnancy, progesterone causes relaxation of smooth muscles, including the ureters. 
  • This leads to reduced ureteral peristalsis and decreased ureteral activity, contributing to hydronephrosis and hydroureter, which are more pronounced on the right side due to uterine dextrorotation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased GFR: The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) increases by approximately 50% during pregnancy to accommodate the increased metabolic and excretory demands of the mother and fetus.

 

Option B. Increased RBF: Renal blood flow (RBF) increases during pregnancy, driven by vasodilation and hormonal changes, which support the elevated GFR.

 

Option C. Hypertrophy of bladder musculature: The bladder musculature undergoes hypertrophy and congestion to adapt to the increased intra-abdominal pressure and changes in urinary storage capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnancy, progesterone relaxes smooth muscles, leading to reduced ureteral activity, which can result in hydroureter and hydronephrosis. 
  • Other urinary changes include increased GFR, RBF, and bladder muscle hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with a 4-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva that involves the urethral meatus. Her medical history includes systemic lupus erythematosus. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

 

  • The involvement of the urethral meatus with a 4-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva indicates a locally advanced vulvar cancer.
  •  The standard treatment for such cases is radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection to remove the primary tumor and assess for lymph node metastases. 
  • This approach is curative and helps prevent regional spread of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic exenteration: Pelvic exenteration involves the removal of multiple pelvic organs and is reserved for patients with recurrent or metastatic disease that has failed primary treatment. It is not indicated for initial management of vulvar cancer with urethral involvement.

 

Option B. Chemoradiation followed by radical vulvectomy: This approach may be used in cases where tumor reduction is required before surgery due to extensive local disease. However, for a resectable tumor involving the urethral meatus, upfront radical surgery is the standard.

 

Option C. Chemoradiation: Chemoradiation alone is used in non-surgical candidates or for palliation, but it is not considered curative for operable vulvar cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For locally advanced vulvar cancer involving the urethral meatus, the standard treatment is radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection to achieve local control and prevent metastasis.

questions.text: A pathologist reviewing a case of suspected ectopic pregnancy finds histological evidence of ovarian tissue in the sac wall, intact fallopian tubes, and attachment to the uterus by the ovarian ligament. Which criteria are used to diagnose this type of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiegelberg criteria

 

  • Spiegelberg criteria are the diagnostic criteria used to confirm ovarian ectopic pregnancy. 

 

These include:

 

  1. The gestational sac must be located in the ovary.
  2. The fallopian tube must be intact and separate from the ovary.
  3. Ovarian tissue must be histologically identified in the wall of the sac.
  4. The gestational sac must be attached to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.

 

These criteria help differentiate ovarian pregnancy from tubal and abdominal ectopic pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring of fire: A term describing the hype vascular appearance around an ectopic pregnancy on Doppler ultrasound. However, this finding is non-specific and can be seen in any type of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Used to assess tubal patency during hysterosalpingography by observing the movement of contrast through the fallopian tubes.

 

Option D. Studdiford criteria: Used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancies.  

 

The criteria include:

 

  • Normal fallopian tubes and ovaries with no evidence of fistula.
  • Evidence of pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Spiegelberg criteria are used to diagnose ovarian ectopic pregnancy and include confirmation of a gestational sac in the ovary, intact fallopian tubes, ovarian tissue in the sac wall, and attachment to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.

choices.text: Perform daily Doppler assessments and wait for improvement
Administer corticosteroids and delay delivery until 36 weeks

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation is found to have an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 5 cm and absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical artery on Doppler ultrasound. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Immediate delivery

 

  • Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical artery indicates severe placental insufficiency and impending fetal compromise. 
  • At 35+3 weeks of gestation, the risk of continuing the pregnancy outweighs the benefits, as the fetus is at significant risk of hypoxia and intrauterine death. 
  • Immediate delivery is recommended regardless of the AFI, as AEDF is an indication of severe fetal distress.
  • Corticosteroids may be administered if delivery can be briefly delayed, but waiting for improvement or prolonging pregnancy in this scenario is not advised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform daily Doppler assessments and wait for improvement: Once AEDF is detected, daily monitoring is insufficient because the condition suggests advanced placental dysfunction. Continuing to wait may lead to intrauterine fetal demise.

 

Option B. Administer corticosteroids and delay delivery until 36 weeks: Corticosteroids are used to enhance fetal lung maturity before 34 weeks, but at 35+3 weeks, the focus is on immediate delivery rather than delaying for lung maturity, as the risks of continuing the pregnancy are high.

 

Option C. Terminate pregnancy after 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks is inappropriate in the setting of AEDF, as this delay places the fetus at significant risk of stillbirth due to worsening placental insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) on umbilical artery Doppler indicates severe placental insufficiency.
  •  Immediate delivery is necessary to prevent fetal hypoxia and intrauterine fetal death, especially after 34 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 34-year-old nulliparous woman in active labor has been pushing for the past two hours without progress and feels extremely fatigued. The CTG remains normal. On examination, the fetal head is 1 cm above the ischial spines and in the occipitoanterior position. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Emergency cesarean section

 

  • In this case, the patient is experiencing a prolonged second stage of labor with no progress despite pushing for two hours. 
  • Although the CTG is reassuring and the fetal head is in the occipitoanterior position, the head remains high (1 cm above the ischial spines). 
  • This indicates that operative vaginal delivery (e.g., forceps or vacuum) is not safe due to the high station of the fetal head, which increases the risk of maternal and fetal trauma. 
  • Therefore, an emergency cesarean section is the most appropriate option to safely deliver the baby and avoid complications for both mother and fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observe for spontaneous progress: Observation is inappropriate as the second stage of labor has already been prolonged, and the patient is fatigued. Further delay increases the risks of maternal exhaustion, uterine rupture, or fetal distress.

 

Option B. Trial of forceps in theater: Operative vaginal delivery is not indicated here because the fetal head is still high (1 cm above the ischial spines), making forceps or vacuum delivery unsafe and prone to complications like excessive traction, maternal trauma, or fetal injury.

 

Option D. Perform fetal blood sampling: Fetal blood sampling is unnecessary in this scenario as the CTG is normal, indicating no immediate concerns about fetal wellbeing. This option does not address the lack of progress in labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For prolonged second-stage labor with no descent of the fetal head and maternal exhaustion, emergency cesarean section is indicated, especially when the fetal station remains high, as operative vaginal delivery in such cases carries significant risks.

A 17-year-old adolescent presents to the gynecology clinic with a history of severe menstrual pain and recurrent pelvic infections since the onset of menstruation. She reports cyclical pain coinciding with her menstrual periods and has experienced occasional urinary tract infections. On physical examination, there is a palpable pelvic mass. Ultrasound imaging reveals a duplicated uterine cavity with one side showing an hematometra and absence of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome

 

  • Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome, also known as Obstructed Hemivagina and Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis (OHVIRA) syndrome, is a rare congenital Müllerian duct anomaly. 
  • It is characterized by a triad of uterus didelphys (double uterus), obstructed hemivagina leading to hematometra or hematocolpos, and absence of the ipsilateral kidney. 
  • The patient’s cyclical pain since menarche, pelvic mass due to hematometra, and ultrasound showing uterine duplication with unilateral renal agenesis are classic features of this condition.
  • Below is an example of a patient who was diagnosed with OHVIRA syndrome:

 

 

A to D: (A) and (B) Contrast-enhanced axial CT image of pelvis shows two separate uterine cavities suggestive of didelphic uterus; (C) Inferior section of the pelvis showing two vaginal cavities separated by a longitudinal septum with distended right hemivagina suggestive of right hematocolpos; (D) Coronal reconstructed image of CT abdomen with absent right kidney

 

Other Options:


Option A. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome: Presents with congenital absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina, leading to primary amenorrhea, not cyclical pain or hematometra.

 

Option B. Asherman’s Syndrome: Occurs due to intrauterine adhesions following uterine curettage or infection, causing secondary amenorrhea and infertility, not congenital anomalies.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: Results from ectopic endometrial tissue causing dysmenorrhea and infertility, but it does not present with uterine duplication or renal agenesis on imaging.

questions.text: A 3-minute-old newborn is being resuscitated due to signs of respiratory distress. Where should the clinical team place the pulse oximeter to measure oxygen saturation in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right upper limb

 

  • In newborn resuscitation, pre-ductal SpO₂ is preferred because it reflects oxygenation before blood mixes through the ductus arteriosus.
  • Right upper limb (typically right hand) is considered pre-ductal, while lower limbs reflect post-ductal oxygen saturation.
  • Importance:
    • Pre-ductal saturation guides initial oxygen therapy in newborns.
    • Post-ductal readings may be lower due to right-to-left shunting across the ductus arteriosus, giving underestimation of arterial oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left upper limb: Can be pre-ductal, but right upper limb is standard for consistency.

 

Option B. Left lower limb: Post-ductal; may underestimate true systemic oxygenation.

 

Option D. Right lower limb: Post-ductal; less reliable for initial resuscitation guidance.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Imaging studies reveal that the neoplasm has metastasized to her lungs. According to the FIGO staging system for GTN, which stage corresponds to this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage III

 

  • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is staged based on the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) classification:
  • Stage I: Disease is confined to the uterus.
  • Stage II: GTN extends to the pelvis and/or vagina.
  • Stage III: GTN has metastasized to the lungs (with or without genital tract involvement).
  • Stage IV: GTN has distant metastasis to organs beyond the lungs (e.g., brain, liver).
  • In this case, lung metastasis is consistent with Stage III disease. GTN with pulmonary metastases can still have a favorable prognosis with appropriate chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, lung metastases classify the disease as Stage III according to FIGO staging. 
  • Proper staging is critical for guiding management and determining prognosis.

A 32-year-old woman, G5P4L4, presents at 10 weeks of gestation with a third-degree uterine prolapse. She reports discomfort and the sensation of a bulge in her vagina, which has worsened since her last pregnancy. Considering her current pregnancy and the degree of prolapse, what would be the most appropriate management option for her condition at this time?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ring pessary

 

  • A ring pessary is the most appropriate management option for a pregnant woman with a third-degree uterine prolapse. 
  • A pessary is a silicone device inserted into the vagina to support the prolapsed uterus, alleviate discomfort, and prevent further descent during pregnancy. 
  • In the context of pregnancy, especially at 10 weeks gestation, a ring pessary helps maintain uterine position, reduces the sensation of bulging, and minimizes complications such as urinary obstruction or increased pelvic pressure. 
  • It is a non-invasive and effective method suitable for managing significant uterine prolapse in pregnant patients, allowing the pregnancy to continue with reduced symptoms and risks associated with prolapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal packing: Vaginal packing is typically used to control acute vaginal bleeding or as a temporary measure in certain gynecological emergencies. It is not a standard treatment for uterine prolapse and does not provide the necessary support to prevent further prolapse or alleviate discomfort associated with a third-degree prolapse.

 

Option B. Cervical cerclage: Cervical cerclage involves placing a stitch around the cervix to prevent premature cervical dilation and is primarily indicated for cervical incompetence to reduce the risk of preterm birth. It is not used to manage uterine prolapse and does not address the structural support needed to maintain uterine position in prolapse cases.

 

Option D. Cervicopexy: Cervicopexy is a surgical procedure that involves fixing the cervix to the pelvic ligaments to provide support. While it can be used in severe cases of prolapse, it is more invasive and not typically the first-line treatment during pregnancy. Non-surgical options like a pessary are preferred to avoid surgical risks and complications during gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ring pessary is the most appropriate and effective non-surgical management option for third-degree uterine prolapse in pregnant women, providing necessary support and alleviating symptoms while minimizing risks during pregnancy.

A neonate is delivered with meconium-stained amniotic fluid. Shortly after birth, the baby has bloody vomitus, and the medical team wants to determine whether the blood is fetal or maternal in origin. Which of the following is the qualitative test used to differentiate fetal blood from maternal blood in such situations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Apt-Downey test

 

  • The Apt-Downey test, also known as the alkali denaturation test, is a qualitative test used to distinguish fetal hemoglobin (HbF) from adult hemoglobin (HbA). 
  • It is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to denaturation in alkaline conditions, while HbA is not. In this test:
    • A sample of blood is treated with an alkali solution (e.g., sodium hydroxide).
    • Fetal hemoglobin remains intact and retains its red color, while adult hemoglobin denatures and turns yellow-brown.
  • This test is particularly useful in differentiating fetal from maternal blood in situations such as bloody vomitus, stool, or amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kleihauer-Betke test: The Kleihauer-Betke test is a quantitative test used to detect and estimate the volume of fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation. It is not a qualitative test and is used in cases of fetomaternal hemorrhage rather than distinguishing blood origin in neonates.

 

Option C. Coombs test: The Coombs test identifies antibodies attached to red blood cells (direct Coombs) or free antibodies in the serum (indirect Coombs). It is unrelated to distinguishing fetal and maternal hemoglobin.

 

Option D. Rho(D) immune globulin titer: This test measures the level of Rho(D) immune globulin, which is used in Rh-negative mothers to prevent sensitization. It does not differentiate between fetal and maternal hemoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Apt-Downey test (alkali denaturation test) is a qualitative test that differentiates fetal hemoglobin (HbF) from maternal hemoglobin (HbA) based on resistance to alkali denaturation. 
  • It is used in clinical settings to identify whether blood in neonatal vomitus, stool, or amniotic fluid is fetal or maternal in origin.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents for vaccination, and the physician discusses options for rotavirus vaccines. Which of the following is a true statement regarding Rotarix and Rotavac vaccines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rotarix is a live attenuated monovalent vaccine targeting serotype G1P[8].

 

  • Rotarix is a monovalent live attenuated vaccine targeting serotype G1P[8], administered orally in a two-dose schedule. 
  • Rotavac is also a live attenuated vaccine but targets serotype G9P[11]. Rotavac is monovalent, not pentavalent. 
  • Both vaccines are administered orally, not intramuscularly. Rotarix follows a two-dose schedule, while Rotavac may follow a two- or three-dose schedule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotavac is a pentavalent vaccine targeting multiple serotypes of rotavirus: Incorrect, as Rotavac is monovalent, not pentavalent.

 

Option C. Both vaccines are subunit vaccines and administered intramuscularly: Incorrect, as both vaccines are live attenuated and administered orally, not subunit or intramuscular vaccines.

 

Option D. Rotarix requires a three-dose schedule as per the National Immunization Schedule: Incorrect, as Rotarix follows a two-dose schedule, not three-dose.
